page.title: 02GEOGRAPHY: BROWNHILLS AREA.
page.content: The area straddles a Bunter sandstone ridge on the eastern side of the South Staffordshire Plateau. This forms a watershed rising to over 180m above sea level. Drainage to the west is to the River Tame whilst to the east it is to the River Trent. Sand and gravel quarries are found flanking this ridge. Geology has also affected land use to the west of the ridge. This is situated on the coal measures and the soil is chiefly marl and clay. Consequently, coalmining and brick making developed. East of the ridge the Triassic rocks, largely sandstone, have favoured agriculture. Relatively fertile soils and proximity to urban areas have resulted in an emphasis on intensive market gardening and cereal production.
